answers.author: Sondra Healy
answers.text:
We had en employee budget committee a year ago that met several times to think of different ways to cut costs and/or generate revenue. I could share how we facilitated that and what I think worked well. I think you are on the right track by thinking of educating employees on how it works. It is a complicated process that can be difficult to communicate to non-finance people.

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
In Manchester, CT, we have an online Employee Suggestion Box where employees can submit recommendations (anonymously if they wish) for our consideration.
As for getting meployees educated, we run a "Government Academy" program whereby residents and staff can enroll and attend a series of courses taught by department heads about their operations.  It's been tremendously popular and successful, and it helps everyone have a better understanding of how the other departments (including budget) contribute to the big picture.

answers.author: Janet Chenard
answers.text:
For the City of Corvallis, Oregon, recent reductions process for the FY 10-11 budget cycle, we utilized several new techniques to get employees more involved/informed, including:

The City Manager hosted about eight separate half-hour "Budget Roadshows" over a one-month period at various City facilities of which all employees' were encouraged (and did!) attend at least one. He spoke to a one-page handout (pg. 6 of the document linked in below) that staff found very effective to aid their understanding of the situation: 
http://www.ci.corvallis.or.us/downloads/fin/FY%2010-11/Budget%20Commission/3_10_10_reduction_status.pdf
  The Finance Director maintained a frequently asked questions site (generated from employee and citizen questions) on the City website through the latter few months of the budget process:
http://www.ci.corvallis.or.us/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3921&Itemid=4467
  The Assistant City Manager convened a group of management and labor union leaders on a regular basis over a 2-month period leading up to FY 10-11 budget adoption (and will reconvene again beginning in September for the next budget process) to consider and work on employee suggestions for cost reductions and/or revenue alternatives. Several good initiatives were spawned through this process, and others were documented for employees' review as to why they could/should not proceed.

answers.author: Paul Rosen
answers.text:
Some governments (in the use of Outcome Based Budgeting) use "Result Teams" to analyze budget requests during the budget process. These teams include a County/City manager liason, department heads, budget analysts, subject matter experts and non-subject matter experts. The teams would come to a conclusion about which "programs" to suggest for the coming year and at what funding level when compared with similar programs trying to reach similar goals. This allowed the department heads and those lower in the organization to not just comment and learn about the budget process, but to actually partake and help create the new budget. Look at The State of Washington, Broward County, FL., and check out "The Price of Government" by Peter Hutchinson and David Osborne.

author: Leslie Beauregard
text:
We are looking for ways to better engage all levels of staff in the upcoming budget process.  Does anyone have some interesting and creative ideas about this?  It's more than about sharing information but about getting ideas, too......and helping staff understand the complete budget picture - this includes educating department heads!
Thanks in advance!
Leslie Beauregard, Director
Budget and Performance Management
title: Staff Engagement in the Budget Process
